description: Current estimate of decimal expansion of reciprocal of fine-structure constant alpha.
comments: The estimate is continually changing.The fine-structure constant actually isn't one, it depends on the energy at which it is measured: Its value is known to approach 1/128 at interaction energies above 80 GeV. For other considerations, e.g., whether the fine-structure constant's value differs by location and over time, see the Wikipedia article or other links. - _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 30 2013
references: John Barrow, The Constants of Nature, 367 pp., Jonathan Cape, 2002.
K. R. Lang, Astrophysical Data: Planets and Stars, Springer-Verlag, NY, 1991.
Martin J. Rees. Just Six Numbers: the deep forces that shape the universe. Phoenix. 1999
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: E. R. Cohen and B. N. Taylor, The 1986 adjustment of the fundamental physical constants, Rev. Modern Phys., 59 (1987), 1121-1148.
Hans de Vries, An exact formula for the Electro Magnetic coupling constant (fine structure constant), 2004.
N. Kosinov, Unexpected Connection of Three Major Constants
N. Kosinov, Connection of Three Major Constants
Robert P. Munafo, Notable Properties of Specific Numbers. [From _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 10 2008]
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _Mira Bernstein_
extensions: Updated by _Omar E. Pol_, Aug 09 2009, by _Raphie Frank_, Dec 13 2012
